Dear Ms. Brewer:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Title qualifications
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
Description following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 touched Youth A inappropriately during a physical
altercation.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed during a previously scheduled
announced visit to the facility on 02/29/2024. At the conclusion of
an interview, she asked if there was any way Licensing could have
the effect of the Chief Administrator and Staff 1 being fired from
the facility. Youth A was informed that could not occur, she then
stated she had an incident of concern regarding Staff 1. Youth A
stated Staff 1 touched her breast during an already escalated
incident a couple weeks prior. Youth A stated she had missed her
dosage of nightly medication on the evening of 02/23/2024
because she had been escalated a few hours prior. Youth A
asked Staff 2 if she could have her medication. Staff 2 told Youth
A she would have to contact the License Designee because she
and Staff 1, who were the only staff present, were not trained to
administer medication to the youth. Youth A stated this upset her
and she decided to go into the staff office to call Law Enforcement
to report concern about her medication. Youth A stated she broke
into the staff office and grabbed the telephone. She then stated
she tried to grab her medications out of the locked cabinet where
they were stored. In doing so, she was able to get ahold of her
medications and she stated Staff 1 tried to take it out of her hands.
Youth A recalled Staff 1 touched her breast. Youth A believed this
was intentional. She recalled Staff 1 did not say anything about
touching her, and only commented about Youth A trying to get
ahold of medication she was not supposed to have in her
possession. Youth A believed Staff 2 would have witnessed this
interaction, but no other youth did because they were all
upstairs. Youth A stated Law Enforcement did come to the facility
later in the evening to address the situation, but she did not have
time to tell them about the touching of her breast.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
03/01/2024. He recalled the incident in question. Staff 1 stated
he was posted in the hallway upstairs with all the other youth in
2

their rooms when Staff 2 came upstairs to speak with him. Staff 2
reported to Staff 1 that Youth A was downstairs and was trying to
break into the staff office. Staff 2 stated he and Staff 1 traded
positions, and he went downstairs. He witnessed Youth A had
already broken into the staff office and was attempting to break
into the locked cabinet that had the prescription medications
stored. Staff 1 recalled taking a container of medications out of
Youth A’s hand without much incident. Staff 1 denied ever
touching her breast in doing so. He did recall Youth A then
immediately walking past him and stating he had touched her
breast.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 2 on
03/11/2024. She stated she was present for the incident in
question. Staff 2 stated she was downstairs when Youth A came
down and asked for her medication that she had refused earlier in
the evening. Staff 2 stated she could not dispense this medication
herself and had to call another staff about it. Staff 2 stated Youth
A then escalated quickly and stated she was going to break into
the locked staff office. Staff 2 stated she alerted Staff 1, and Staff
1 came downstairs to interact with Youth A. Staff 2 saw the entire
interaction between Staff 1 and Youth A and stated she never saw
Staff 1 touch Youth A in an inappropriate manner.
DHHS Worker 1 held a video conference on 04/01/2024 where
she confirmed there would be no findings as a result of her
investigation.
Documents reviewed:
• As a result of the initial allegations the facility instituted the
following safety plan: There was to be no direct interaction
between Youth A and Staff 1 and he was to never be alone
with Youth A pending the results of investigations.
• Two Incident Reports dated 02/23/2024 were provided and
reviewed. They were authored by Staff 1 and Staff 2
respectively and were consistent with the interviews they
provided.
• Discipline within the staff file of Staff 1 was
reviewed. There were five areas of coaching or discipline
notes since January 2024, including matters regarding his
personal items onsite, no-shows for scheduled shifts, use
of personal phone during working hours, and a write up for
insubordination. Staff 1 ended his employment with the
facility on 03/16/2024.
3

Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed there was not enough evidence found that Youth A was
touched inappropriately during the incident in question.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility is advised to have clear safety plan
documentation including dates and authors.
Conclusion Violation not established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(d) Storage of medications.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Prescription medication was not stored properly.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed during a previously scheduled
announced visit to the facility on 02/29/2024. During her
description of the incident in question she stated she tried to grab
her medications out of the locked cabinet where they were
stored. Youth A said the cabinet is located inside of the locked
office area. Youth A stated the cabinet was locked at the time, but
the doors do not close tightly. She recalled being able to reach up
behind the closed doors of the cabinet and she was able to take
any item out that she attempted. She was able to get ahold of her
medications and she stated Staff 1 tried to take it out of her hands.
During the announced visit on 02/29/2024 the office area was
viewed. Inside this office area there is a locked cabinet above a
desk where medication was stored. It was locked with a keyed
cabinet lock, but the doors were loose enough for easy access to
the contents of the cabinet even with the doors closed.
Documents reviewed:
• Policy & procedure titled “Health Services: Policies and
Procedures” was reviewed. In this policy it was stated
“medications must be kept in locked compartments under
proper temperature.”
Analysis Through interviews with youth, documentation reviewed and an
on-site inspection there was evidence found that the facility failed
4

to properly store youth’s medication, allowing them to gain access
to it at their will.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility is advised to seek better solutions to the
storage of medications. The incident in question may not
have escalated to the point of physical contact had the
medication been stored in a manner that was clearly safe
and secured.
• The facility is advised to explore expanded medication
administration training among staff. The incident in
question may not have escalated further had there been
more availability of a staff member that could administer
medication at any given time.
Conclusion Violation established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Based on the findings in this report a CAP is required.
Per SIR #2024C0001037SI, a 1st provisional license is recommended.
